sources.full: The Adventures of Torrin Campaign Setting

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Dragon
entries: Some warriors are born in the depths of a dragon’s lair where they absorb the lingering magic in the area, allowing them to channel it into their burning rage.

Most barbarian tribes who worship dragonkind usually revere them as gods for their unmatched strength and frightening auras. Barbarians who can harness their dragonkin’s powers are often regarded as the strongest of their tribes.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Ancestor
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to speak, read, and write Draconic or one other language of your choice. In addition, you’ve grown up around dragons, inheriting some of their magic. Choose chromatic, gem, or metallic. You can then choose one damage type that is associated with your chosen draconic ancestor. The damage type you choose is used by features you gain later.

entries.caption: Draconic Ancestor
rows: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison

entries: If a feature from this subclass requires a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Fury of The Dragon
entries: At 3rd level, you can channel draconic energy into your weapon strikes. While you're raging, the first creature you hit on each of your turns with a weapon attack takes extra damage equal to {@dice 1d6}. The extra damage is the damage type associated with your draconic ancestor.
The extra damage increases to {@dice 2d6} at 9th level and {@dice 3d6} at 16th level.

subclassFeature.name: Rage of The Dragon
entries: Also at 3rd level, when you enter your rage your body becomes riddled with dragon scales as you undergo a draconic transformation. While raging, you gain a bonus to your AC equal to your Rage Damage found on the Barbarian table, provided you are not wearing any armor.
In addition, you gain resistance to the damage type associated with your draconic ancestor while raging.

subclassFeature.name: Breath of The Raging Dragon
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can channel the draconic energies within and exhale it into a powerful magical burst. While raging when you take the Attack action on your turn, you can replace one of the attacks with an exhalation of draconic energy in either a 20-foot cone or a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide (your choice). Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw. They take {@dice 2d10} damage of the type associated with your draconic ancestor on a failed save, or half as much on a success.
At 13th level, the damage of this feature increases to {@dice 3d10} and {@dice 4d10} at 17th level.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. While you have no uses available, you can expend a use of your rage to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Wings of The Raging Dragon
entries: Starting at 10th level, when you enter your rage, or as a bonus action on subsequent turns while raging, you can furl or unfurl dragon-like wings from your body. While unfurled, your wings grant you a flying speed equal to your walking speed. If you already had a flying speed, it is increased by an amount equal to half your walking speed.

If you are wearing armor, to unfurl your wings your armor must be made to accommodate them. When your rage ends, your wings instantly become furled, causing you to fall if you were still flying when they furl.

subclassFeature.name: Frightening Rage
entries: At 14th level, when you enter your rage you create an aura of frightening power. At the start of each of their turns, every creature that can see or hear you within 30 feet of you must make a Wisdom saving throw or become frightened of you for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a successful save.
A creature that succeeds their saving throw is immune to this aura’s effect for 1 hour.

subclassFeature.name: The Greatwyrm
entries: There are dragons that have ascended to near god-hood known as greatwyrms. It is no secret that dragons can bestow their powers as gifts onto other creatures, there are even dragons that are gods in the D&D multiverse that bestow their powers onto clerics as divine power.

Greatwyrms are similar in nature to these divine dragons, but on a lesser scale typically. As such, they are just as capable as bestowing power to devout followers. Some greatwyrms have cult-like followings, others give their powers to great heroes and some are even children to these great beings.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: Starting at 1st level, the greatwyrm lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

entries.caption: Expanded Spell List
rows: {@spell circle of power|PHB}, {@spell summon draconic spirit|FTD}

subclassFeature.name: Eye of Dragonsight
entries: Starting at 1st level, you have the ability to perceive echoes of yourself and your dragon patron, allowing yourself to gain the knowledge and some abilities of these echoes. When you finish a short or long rest, choose one skill or tool you lack proficiency in. You gain proficiency in that skill or tool, which lasts until you finish your next short or long rest.

As an action, you can focus your dragonsight and allow yourself to see spirits. You can see into the ethereal plane out to a range of 60 feet, as if you were under the effects of the {@spell see invisibility} spell. You can retain this sight for 1 minute or until you lose your concentration (as if you were concentrating on a spell).
You can focus your dragonsight a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Gift
entries: Also at 1st level, you have a gift from your patron that physically changes you. You gain the following benefits:

items.name: Tongue of Dragons
entries: You learn to speak, read, and write Draconic or one other language of your choice.

items.name: Draconic Spells
entries: When you finish a short rest, choose from acid, cold, fire, force, lightning, necrotic, poison, psychic, radiant, or thunder. When you damage a target with a spell, you can change the damage of the spell to the chosen type.

items.name: Dragon's Wrath
entries: Once during each of your turns when you hit with an attack roll, you can deal extra damage equal to your proficiency bonus. The type of damage is determined by the type chosen by your draconic spells benefit.

subclassFeature.name: Voice of The Greatwyrm
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can channel the voice of your patron to boom through yours. As an action, you can give yourself advantage on all Charisma ability checks for the next 10 minutes. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses of it once you complete a short or long rest.
Alternatively, when you have no remaining uses of this ability you can expend a warlock spell slot to use it again.
In addition, you have advantage on saving throws made to resist being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

subclassFeature.name: Flight of The Greatwyrm
entries: Starting at 10th level, as a bonus action, you can form spectral wings and give yourself a flying speed of 60 feet that lasts for 10 minutes, during which you can hover. You can use this bonus action a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Versatile Dragon Spells
entries: Also at 10th level, when you would change the type of damage a spell would use with your Draconic Spells benefit, you can choose a different type from the same list. You can use this feature twice, regaining all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.
Alternatively, you can expend a warlock spell slot to use this feature again when you have no remaining uses of it.

subclassFeature.name: Ward of The Greatwyrm
entries: At 14th level, you can use a bonus action and a warlock spell slot to cast the {@spell Primordial Ward|XGE} spell. When you cast this spell in this way, you do not need to concentrate on it and its casting time is the bonus action used for it.

Alternatively, you can cast the spell in the same way but as an action instead, doing so gives you the ability to choose a creature within 30 feet of you that you can see and give them the benefits of the spell instead of yourself.

subclassFeature.name: Magitechnician
entries: Intermingling human technologies with the magic veiling the multiverse, you are able to create products of immense power and efficiency. Your creations are the bi-product of technological advancement and the study of the arcane. With mastery of both studies, you leave your enemies awestruck and wasted by your various gadgets and devices.

subclassFeature.name: Magitech Spells
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you always have certain spells prepared after you reach particular levels in this class, as shown in the Magitechnician Spells table. These spells count as artificer spells for you, but they don't count against the number of artificer spells you prepare.

subclassFeature.name: Magitech Inventor
entries: Starting at 3rd level, choose two tools you have proficiency in. Your proficiency bonus is doubled when you make ability checks using either of the chosen tools.

In addition, you can choose two infusions among the following: {@optfeature Magitech Gadget|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}, {@optfeature Magitech Attachment|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}, {@optfeature Magitech Vehicle|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}, {@optfeature Magitech Construct|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}, or {@optfeature Magitech Tool|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}. These infusions are added to your infusions known, but do not count towards the limit of infusions known and you can infuse two additional items when you complete a long rest, but they must be an infusion chosen from this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Combative Engineer
entries: Also at 3rd level, when you attack with a magic weapon, you can use your Intelligence modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity modifier, for the attack and damage rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Magitech Gear
entries: Starting at 5th level, when you finish a long rest you can magically transform up to two non-magical weapons and one set of non-magical light or medium armor into magitech variants, thereby making them magical. You gain proficiency with the weapon if you did not have it already. When you wear a set of magitech armor, you can add your Intelligence modifier instead of your Dexterity modifier to your AC (the maximum Dexterity modifier restriction to medium armor also applies to your Intelligence modifier). You can still apply infusions to items that were transformed into magitech variants.
When you damage a target with a magitech weapon, you can change the damage type to force.

You can only have up to two magitech weapons and one set of magitech armor at any given time, and they remain as their magitech until you spend an action to dismiss the magic keeping them transformed or until you die.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Magitech Research
entries: At 9th level, you can choose one additional infusion from the list provided by your Magitech Inventor feature, count towards the limit of infusions known and you can infuse two additional items when you complete a long rest, but it must be one of the infusions chosen by this class’ subclass features.

subclassFeature.name: Magitech Energy
entries: Starting at 9th level, you’ve discovered how to draw in the magic around you and channel it into condensed energy, allowing you to use that energy in a variety of ways. You have a number of magitech energy equal to twice your Intelligence modifier. You can use magitech energy in the following ways:

items.name: Disruptive Barrier
entries: When you would be hit by an attack, you can spend 1 to 5 magitech energy as a reaction to increase your AC by 1 per magitech energy spent against the triggering attack, potentially turning a hit into a miss.

items.name: Weapon Surge
entries: As a bonus action, you can spend 1 to 3 magitech energy and channel it into one of your magitech weapons. The next time you hit with a magitech weapon, it deals an additional {@dice 1d8} of force damage per magitech energy spent.

items.name: Ability Boost
entries: When you would fail an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, you can expend 1 to 3 magitech energy to gain a +2 bonus to the roll per magitech energy spent.
You regain all expended magitech energy when you finish a long rest, or you can use a bonus action to spend a spell slot to regain an amount of magitech energy equal to the level of the spent slot.

subclassFeature.name: Magitech Mastery
entries: Starting at 15th level, you can transform magical weapons and armor into magitech variants using your Magitech Gear feature and you can even apply infusions to these items, despite them already being magical. Magitech items that you are attuned to does not count against the total number of attunement slots you have.
In addition, whenever you hit a creature with a magitech weapon, the creature takes an extra {@dice 1d8} force damage.

subclassFeature.name: The Rune Blade
entries: Not all sorcerers obtain their magic from their blood directly, sometimes it’s a magical gift granted to them later on in their life. This gift may be passed on through generations, either through their family line or as a renowned prophecy of inheritance.

subclassFeature.name: Rune Magic
entries: Your magic is drawn from the oldest forms of magic, which grants you access to certain spells. You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Rune Blade Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be an {@filter abjuration or conjuration spell from the sorcerer, warlock, or wizard spell list|spells|class=sorcerer;warlock;wizard|school=a,c|level=1;2;3;4;5}

entries.caption: Rune Blade Spells
rows: {@spell hex}, {@spell protection from evil and good}
{@spell circle of power}, {@spell steel wind strike|XGE}

subclassFeature.name: Runic Weapon
entries: At 1st level, you’ve discovered an ancient magical secret that allows you to form a melee weapon with runes. By performing a 10-minute ritual you can create this magical weapon. It counts as a martial melee weapon with the finesse and light properties. You are proficient with this weapon and you can use it as a spellcasting focus. It deals 1d6 damage of your choosing from bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage. You can only have one runic weapon created by this feature at a time. The damage increases to 1d8 at 6th level and 1d10 at 14th level.

Alternatively, by performing a similar 10-minute ritual, you can transform a weapon you are proficient with into a runic weapon, using its statistics instead but you can also use it as an spellcasting focus. This transformation lasts until you finish a long rest or until you die. You can perform this ritual once, regaining the ability to do so again when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Blade Runes
entries: Also at 1st level, magical runes appear on your runic weapons. Choose two of the listed runes below, you learn how to scribe these runes on your runic weapons, which you can do after you complete a long rest or when you perform the ritual to create and or transform them. You can only have one rune active at a time.

entries.name: Haug Rune
entries: This rune's magic bestows a resilience reminiscent of a hill giant. As a bonus action, you can bestow the wielder of this weapon resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical attacks.

In addition, when you hit a creature with an attack made with this weapon, once a round you can force that creature to make a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, they are knocked prone or pushed back 5 feet (your choice).

entries.name: Ild Rune
entries: This rune’s magic gives you the fiery powers of ancient giants. As a bonus action, you can ignite the flames on this weapon changing its properties. When you damage a target with an attack made with this weapon, you can change the damage type of the weapon to fire damage.

In addition, while the rune is active, magical flames veil your body. When you are hit with a melee attack, you can spend your reaction to deal 2d6 fire damage to the attacker as the flames lash out at the creature.

entries.name: Ise Rune
entries: This rune's magic evokes a frost giant's stoic calm. As a bonus action, you can evoke a cold energy onto this weapon changing its properties. When you damage a target with an attack made with this weapon, you can change the damage type of the weapon to cold damage.

In addition, while the rune is active provided you aren’t wearing medium or heavy armor, you gain a bonus to your AC equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of +1) as magical ice forms around your body as a protective shell.

entries.name: Rune of Dragon's Might
entries: This rune’s magic contains the powerful might of dragons. As a bonus action, you can evoke this magic and empower yourself with it. You have advantage on Strength-based attack rolls, Strength ability checks, and Strength saving throws.
In addition, your movement speed is increased by 10 feet and moving out of a creature’s reach does not provoke opportunity attacks.

entries.name: Rune of Ancient Horrors
entries: This rune’s magic contains the ancient horrors of aberrant creatures. As a bonus action you can release this rune’s magic changing your weapon’s properties. When you damage a creature with this weapon, you can force that creature to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, they become frightened of you for one minute. They can repeat their save at the end of each of their turns, ending the effect on a success.

In addition, while this rune is active when you are hit by a melee attack by a creature, you can spend your reaction to release a tendril from the far realm to grab onto the attacker. They become grappled for 1 minute. They can use an action to attempt to escape the grapple with an escape DC equal to your spell save DC.

entries.name: Uvar Rune
entries: Using this rune’s magic, you can evoke the power of storms. As a bonus action, you can change the properties of your weapon using this rune’s magic. When you damage a target with an attack made with this weapon, you can change the damage type of the weapon to lightning damage.

In addition, while this rune is active when you would be hit by a melee attack by a creature, you can spend your reaction and roll a d6. You can reduce the attack roll by the number rolled on the d6, potentially turning a hit into a miss.

Alternatively, using the same bonus action you use to activate these runes, or a bonus action on subsequent turns, you can give the benefits of that rune to different creature that you can see within 30 feet of you for 1 minute, after which the rune returns back to you. You cannot gain the benefits of that rune again until that creature loses the given rune. You can use a bonus action to switch the target of that rune to a different creature, or switch it back to yourself.
When you give these runes to another creature, the runes appear on one of their weapons that they are holding.

You can activate your runes a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Alternatively, when you have no remaining uses of your runes, you can expend a spell slot of any level to regain one use of your runes. Any rune that has been activated remains active for 1 hour or until you dismiss them (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Additional Blade Runes
entries: At 6th level, you learn two additional runes from your Blade Runes feature.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. Moreover, you can cast one of your cantrips in place of one of those attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Blade Runes
entries: At 14th level, you learn two additional runes from your Blade Runes feature.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Rune Magic
entries: Also at 14th level, you can have two runes active at a time instead of one. Also, as a bonus action on your turn you can flare a burst of runic energy by expending 3 sorcery points. Until the end of your next turn, you can activate one of your inert runes regardless of how many you have active, but only on yourself.
In addition, when you hit with a weapon attack using a runic weapon, you add a bonus to the damage roll equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of +1).

subclassFeature.name: Runic Master
entries: Starting at 18th level, you can have 3 runes active at a time. Also, you can use a bonus action to immediately end one of the effects of your active runes to regain an expended spell slot of 3rd level or lower.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Tempest
entries: Born with the might of dragons, elementals, giants, or other similar stormborn creatures, you follow a monastic tradition that teaches you to harness the power of a raging storm that brews within you. When you focus your ki, you can align yourself with the storm inside you and bend them to your will, using them as an extension of your body.
Many monks of this tradition tattoo their bodies with representations of their ki powers, commonly imagined as coiling dragons, but also as elder tempests and arcane sigils.

subclassFeature.name: Channel The Storm
entries: {@i 3rd-level Tempest Feature}

You can call upon the might of a raging tempest that lies deep within your soul. Once per round on your turn, you can add bonus lightning or thunder damage (you choose when you use this feature) to your monk weapons or unarmed strikes when you hit with them. This bonus equals your martial arts die.

subclassFeature.name: Step of the Tempest
entries: {@i 3rd-level Tempest Feature}
When you use your Step of the Wind feature, you can spend an additional ki point to increase your movement speed by an additional 10 feet until the end of the turn.

subclassFeature.name: Stormlord's Protection
entries: {@i 6th-level Tempest Feature}
You gain resistance to lightning and thunder damage.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Disciple
entries: {@i 6th-level Tempest Feature}

You can channel your inner storm into magical spells and other magical abilities. Choose one of three styles: Dragon, Giant, or Primordial. You can cast certain spells depending on your chosen style using ki points. The spell save DC is equal to your Ki Save DC and you use your Wisdom modifier for determining your spell attack bonus. You do not require material components to cast these spells, even costly ones.

entries.name: Dragon
entries: You can spend 3 ki points to cast {@spell dragon's breath|XGE} (you can only choose lightning), 4 ki points to cast {@spell lightning bolt}, or 4 ki points to cast {@spell fly}.

entries.name: Giant
entries: You can spend 3 ki points to cast {@spell augury}, 4 ki points to cast {@spell call lightning}, or 4 ki points to cast {@spell thunder step|XGE}.

entries.name: Primordial
entries: You can spend 3 ki points to cast {@spell gust of wind}, 4 ki points to cast {@spell elemental weapon} (you can only choose lightning or thunder damage), or 4 ki points to cast {@spell wind wall}.

subclassFeature.name: Stormborn's Tempest
entries: {@i 11th-level Tempest Feature}
As a bonus action you can spend a ki point to channel a powerful storm that coils around your body for 1 minute. While active, you gain the following benefits:

items: You gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed and can hover.
Whenever you deal an amount of lightning or thunder damage each creature that takes damage takes an additional amount of lighting or thunder damage equal to your proficiency bonus.
Whenever you are hit by a melee attack from a creature within 5ft of you, they take an amount of lightning or thunder damage equal to your proficiency bonus.

entries: Once your Stormborn’s Tempest ends, you cannot enter it again until you finish a long rest, or if you expend 3 ki points to regain the ability to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Grandmaster
entries: {@i 17th-level Tempest Feature}

You’ve mastered the magical power within, granting you additional spells and abilities at your disposal. As an action, you gain immunity to lightning and thunder damage for the next minute. Once you do so, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest, or you expend 3 ki points to regain a use of this feature.
In addition, depending on which style you chose at 6th level, you can cast the following spells using ki:

entries.name: Dragon
entries: You can spend 5 ki points to cast {@spell freedom of movement}, 6 ki points to cast {@spell destructive wave}, or 7 ki points to cast {@spell chain lightning}.

entries.name: Giant
entries: You can spend 5 ki points to cast {@spell storm sphere|XGE}, 6 ki points to cast {@spell steel wind strike|XGE} (the damage dealt is lightning or thunder damage instead of force), or 7 ki points to cast {@spell scatter|XGE}.

entries.name: Primordial
entries: You can spend 5 ki points to cast {@spell summon elemental|TCE} (you can only choose air), 6 ki points to cast {@spell control winds|XGE}, or 7 ki points to cast {@spell investiture of wind|XGE}.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Rune Keeper
entries: Some monks serve as lifelong guardians for ancient and sacred treasures, these monks tattoo themselves with runes and empower themselves with ancient magic from a long forgotten time.

subclassFeature.name: Ki of The Keeper
entries: Starting at 3rd level, using ancient runes tattooed on your body, you can empower your ki. You gain the following benefits:

items: When you use your Patient Defense feature, you gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage until the start of your next turn.

When you use your Step of The Wind feature, you can immediately escape from being grappled or restrained, no ability check or save required. In addition, you have advantage on ability checks and saving throws made to resist being grappled or restrained until the start of your next turn.

When you use your Flurry of Blows feature, you can force a creature’s attention to focus on you, marking them with ancient magic. Each time you hit a creature with your Flurry of Blows, they must make a Wisdom saving throw against your Ki Save DC. On a failed save, they have disadvantage on any attack roll that doesn't target you until the start of your next turn. During that time, each time they deal damage to a creature other than you, they take force damage equal to one roll of your martial arts die.

subclassFeature.name: Guardian Runes
entries: Also at 3rd level, your vitality is protected by powerful runes tattooed on your body. Your hit point maximum increases by 3 and increases by 1 again whenever you gain a level in this class.
In addition, you have advantage on saving throws made to resist being poisoned or diseased.

subclassFeature.name: Protective Runes
entries: At 6th level, you can use your runic magic to protect your allies from harm. As a reaction when you see a creature within 60 feet of you take damage, you can expend 2 ki points to half the damage they would have taken (round down). You take the other half of the damage.
You can use this reaction a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Disciple of The Runes
entries: Also at 6th level, you can spend 2 ki points to cast {@spell arcane lock}, {@spell protection from evil and good}, or {@spell protection from poison}, without providing material components. You can cast them normally, or you can spend an additional ki point to cast them as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Guardian's Touch
entries: Starting at 11th level, as an action you can touch a creature and protect them against the jaws of death, which lasts for 1 hour. During this time, the next time they would be reduced to 0 hit points or die, they are instead reduced to 1 hit point. Afterwhich, the next time they would take damage they can choose to take no damage instead.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest. While you have no uses available, you can spend 3 ki points to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Ward of The Keeper
entries: At 17th level, you can use an action to touch a creature other than yourself and bestow them with a protective ward for 1 minute. While they have this ward, they gain a bonus to their AC equal to your Wisdom modifier.
Once you’ve given this ward, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest. While you have no uses available, you can spend 5 ki points to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Extraplanar Summoner
entries: {@i 1st-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

Born with a connection to planar magic, sorcerers of this origin are capable of summoning creatures of varying origins. Aberrations, celestials, constructs, fey, fiends, monstrosities, and even undead creatures can be conjured by these odd spellcasters. Your innate magic comes from the other planes, such as the feywild, shadowfell, the outer planes such as the abyss, nine hells, or even mount celestia.

Extraplanar summoners are extremely handy to have due to the powerful allies they can conjure, however they are tied directly to you, so keeping yourself alive is just as important as keeping your ally healthy.

subclassFeature.name: Summoner Magic
entries: Your magic comes from the planes outside the material one, granting you powerful conjuration magic. You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Extraplanar Summoner Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be a {@filter conjuration spell from the sorcerer, warlock, or wizard spell list|spells|class=sorcerer;warlock;wizard|school=C|level=1;2;3;4;5}.

subclassFeature.name: Extraplanar Ally
entries: {@i 1st-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

As an action, you bind another creature’s soul from another plane to your whim and place it within a body you magically conjure. Choose one of the following creature types: aberration, celestial, construct, elemental, fey, fiend, monstrosity, or undead. Depending on the creature type you chose, use the corresponding Extraplanar Ally stat block. The creature obeys your commands and is friendly to you and your allies. It shares your initiative but moves and takes actions either right before or after your turn. If you are reduced to 0 hit points and are knocked unconscious, your connection to the planar ally ends and it returns to the plane from once it came. You can use an action and spend a spell slot of any level to summon it again, but it returns with the hit points and conditions it had prior to returning to its plane.

In addition to summoning the creature, you gain a magical benefit depending on the creature type you chose. You gain one of the following benefits until the Extraplanar Ally is destroyed or returns to its home plane:

entries.name: Aberration
entries: You gain the ability to speak telepathically to creatures you can see within 60 ft of you. In addition, you can reach into the minds of other creatures and cripple them. You can cast the {@spell Vicious Mockery} cantrip as if it were a sorcerer spell for you.

entries.name: Celestial
entries: You gain resistance to radiant damage and can spend your bonus action to heal a creature within 30 ft of you a number of hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Construct
entries: You gain resistance to non-magical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage and as a bonus action you can change the damage type of your next spell to force damage until the end of your next turn. You concentrate on this effect as if you were concentrating on a spell.

entries.name: Elemental
entries: Choose fire, water, earth, or air. In the Extraplanar Ally (Elemental) statblock you use the features corresponding to the chosen type. You gain resistance to poison damage and have advantage on saving throws against being poisoned.

entries.name: Fey
entries: You gain resistance to psychic damage and you have advantage on saving throws against being charmed.

entries.name: Fiend
entries: You gain resistance to fire damage you can see normally in darkness, both magical and nonmagical, to a distance of 60 feet.

entries.name: Monstrosity
entries: You gain a natural weapon in the form of claws or fangs. These natural weapons use your spellcasting ability modifier instead of strength or dexterity for its attack and damage rolls and deal 1d6 slashing or piercing damage (your choice). In addition your armor class increases by half your proficiency bonus (rounded up).

entries.name: Undead
entries: You gain resistance to necrotic damage and whenever you deal damage with a spell you can add an additional amount of necrotic damage to the spell equal to your proficiency bonus.

Your Extraplanar Ally is destroyed when it is reduced to 0 hit points or if it is successfully banished via the Banishment spell, or other similar effect. When it is destroyed, its soul returns to its home plane. It retains no memories from when it was traveling with you while on its home plane and when it is summoned again it regains the lost memories. After your Extraplanar Ally is destroyed, you cannot summon it again until you finish a long rest.

You cannot have more than one Extraplanar Ally at any given time. You can dismiss your Extraplanar Ally as an action, or freely during a short or long rest. Once you dismiss your Extraplanar Ally, you cannot summon a new one until you have finished a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Summoner Savant
entries: {@i 6th-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

When you cast a conjuration spell of 1st level or higher, you can choose to ignore the material cost of the spell. When you do so, you must use an arcane focus, but it does not get consumed by the spell.
You use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus and regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Synergist
entries: {@i 6th-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

Your Extraplanar Ally adds your proficiency bonus to its damage rolls for its weapon attacks. Your Extraplanar’s attacks are considered magical for the purposes of overcoming non-magical resistances. In addition, the benefit you gain from your Extraplanar Ally feature gets improved based on the creature type, the following changes (or additions) are made to said benefit:

entries.name: Aberration
entries: You add an additional amount of psychic damage to {@spell Vicious Mockery|PHB} equal to your proficiency bonus and your telepathy’s range increases to 120 ft.

entries.name: Celestial
entries: When you heal a creature using the benefit you gain from your Extraplanar Ally feature, you can spend sorcery points up to your proficiency bonus to add 1d4 healing per sorcery point spent.

entries.name: Construct
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being paralyzed.

entries.name: Elemental
entries: You have immunity to poison damage instead of resistance.

entries.name: Fey
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being frightened.

entries.name: Fiend
entries: You can see normally in darkness, magical or nonmagical, to a range of 120 ft instead of 60ft.

entries.name: Monstrosity
entries: Your speed increases by 15 ft and you gain an amount of temporary hit points equal to twice your proficiency bonus when you gain this feature, finish a long rest, or summon your Extraplanar Ally as a monstrosity.

entries.name: Undead
entries: When you hit a creature with a spell, you can spend 2 sorcery points to make that creature unable to gain the benefits of healing until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Combative Ally
entries: {@i 14th-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}
Your Extraplanar Ally gets multiattack, allowing it to make up to two attacks instead of one when it takes the attack action.

In addition, as a bonus action on your turn you can spend a sorcery point to give a number of temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus to your Extraplanar Ally if it is within 60 ft of you.

subclassFeature.name: Extraplanar Master
entries: {@i 18th-level Extraplanar Summoner feature}

You can summon an Extraplanar Ally two times instead of once before you have to finish a long rest if it is destroyed or dismissed, but you can still only have one summoned Extraplanar Ally at any given time.

In addition when you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, your Extraplanar Ally receives an amount of healing equal to the spell's level plus your proficiency bonus. This healing bypasses its Constructed Body feature.
Your Extraplanar Ally, and creatures you summon using a Conjuration spell of 1st level or higher gain an amount of temporary hit points when they are summoned equal to your sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Remedies
entries: Nature provides natural forms of remedies for poisons, disease, illness, and wounds. Druids a part of this circle are particularly skilled in taking these natural remedies and magically enhancing them, dedicating their lives to preserving the lives of their circle and the lives of the creatures of their terrain.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Many druids form a connection to nature, but few to this level. Your connection to the natural world grants you access to some spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Circle of Remedies Spells table.

Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

entries.caption: Circle of Remedies Spells
rows: {@spell speak with plants}, {@spell mass healing word}

subclassFeature.name: Natural Herbalist
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your proficiency bonus is doubled when you make an ability check using a herbalism kit. In addition, you gain proficiency in Nature and Survival and your proficiency bonus is doubled when making an ability check using those skills.
In addition, you are an expert at brewing potions of healing. The cost and time required for you to craft potions of healing is halved.

subclassFeature.name: Remedies of The Wild
entries: Also at 2nd level, by performing a 10 minute ritual you can magically create special herbs that can be used as medical remedies. You create a number of these remedies equal to your proficiency bonus, choosing from the following remedies for each one:

entries.name: Remedy of Wound Closure
entries: A creature may use a bonus action to quickly chew on this remedy, igniting regenerative properties. They magically regain 1d6 plus your Wisdom modifier hit points and any scars, magical or non-magical, are removed. This healing has no effect on undead or constructs and has no effects on unconscious creatures.

entries.name: Remedy of Curing
entries: A creature may use a bonus action to consume this remedy, removing any poisons or diseases afflicting them.

entries.name: Remedy of Revitalization
entries: A creature may use an action to break this remedy and release a magical vapor which rejuvenates an {@condition unconscious} creature. An {@condition unconscious} creature that is not at 0 hit points becomes awake and conscious again, unless they are cursed to be {@condition unconscious}. A creature at 0 hit points and is {@condition unconscious} regains 1 hit point and regains consciousness, instantly coming to their feet with a burst of energy.
A creature may also use an action to apply these remedies to another creature.

Once you create these magical remedies, they last for 24 hours until they lose their potency and you cannot create them again until you finish a short or long rest. The first time you use this feature after each long rest, you can create these magical remedies without expending a spell slot. All other times you expend a spell slot of 1st-level or higher.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Remedies
entries: At 6th level, the list of remedies you can create expands as your knowledge of remedies increases:

entries.name: Remedy of Restoration
entries: A creature can use an action to apply this remedy to themselves or another creature, allowing them to remove one condition listed in the {@spell lesser restoration} spell.

entries.name: Remedy of Heightened Senses
entries: A creature can use a bonus action to apply this remedy on their eyes and ears. The creature has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks and gains the benefits of the {@spell see invisibility} spell for 1 hour. After the hour has passed, the creature becomes blinded and deafened for 1 minute as pain swells up in their eyes and ears suffering the drawback of the remedy.

subclassFeature.name: Nature's Guardian
entries: Also at 6th level, while you are transformed by Wild Shape, you can use a bonus action to expend one spell slot to have yourself, or a creature you can see within 30 feet of you regain 1d6 hit points per level of the spell slot expended. Regardless of how many dice you roll, you add your Wisdom modifier to the total amount of hit points restored.

In addition, as a bonus action while in your Wild Shape form or your normal form, you can gain a restorative aura that heals your allies that extends out to a 10-foot radius which lasts for 1 minute. Each creature (other than yourself) that starts its turn in the aura, or enters it for the first time on its turn, regains a number of hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.
A creature can recover hit points from this aura a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining the ability to heal from it again when they finish a long rest.
Once you create this aura, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest unless you expend a 3rd-level or higher spell slot to regain a use of the aura.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Remedies
entries: At 10th level, the list of remedies you can create expands as your knowledge of remedies increases:

entries.name: Remedy of Adrenaline
entries: A creature can use a bonus action to inhale this remedy, granting them a boost in motor functions. They gain the benefits of the {@spell haste} spell for a number of rounds equal to your proficiency bonus. They suffer from the lethargy the haste spell gives after the benefits ends.

entries.name: Remedy of Stone Melting
entries: A creature can use an action to apply this remedy onto a {@condition petrified} creature. At the end of the {@condition petrified} creature’s next turn, they are no longer {@condition petrified}.

subclassFeature.name: Champion of Nature
entries: At 14th level, you’ve achieved the peak of your magical abilities. There is no longer a limit to how many times a creature can heal from your aura created by your Nature’s Guardian feature and the aura becomes a 20-foot radius. In addition, you also regain hit points at the start of your turns while your aura is active.

Also, when you restore hit points to a creature using a spell of 1st-level or higher, or when they would restore hit points from one of your remedies, they regain an additional amount of hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: College of Minstrel
entries: The College of Minstrel cannot be found on any map, nor is it defined to one location. No one place is defined as home to these bards, rather, they consider those they travel with their true home. The world is their home, and the people in it are mere extensions of their family. These bards protect their family as they would themselves and focus on healing. These bards also have a particular liking to poetry and songs, as it spreads joy to those who listen.

subclassFeature.name: Traveler's Song
entries: At 3rd level, while travelling or spending downtime you can play a song that keeps your allies focused and determined on their tasks.

Provided your allies can see or hear you during the task, they have advantage on any ability checks associated with the task. When you use this feature, you are assumed to be spending your own ability to partake in downtime activities or other tasks during travel, however you may still partake in certain tasks, such as performing at a tavern if the allies you are aiding are in said tavern, with approval by your DM.
In addition, one of those creatures may add a bonus to one of their rolls equal to one roll of your bardic inspiration die.

As an example, a Ranger who goes hunting for resources during downtime can have advantage on their Wisdom (Survival) ability check in addition to any other ability checks associated with hunting. Or, if you are traveling at a slow pace to stealth during your travel for safety, you and your allies can have advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks, provided they can see you. A wizard who is trying to sell a magic item in a tavern may still allow you to perform entertainment for the tavern and grant the benefits to the wizard.

subclassFeature.name: Minstrel's Melody
entries: Also at 3rd level, when a 1st level or higher spell you cast would restore a creature’s hit points, you can spend a Bardic Inspiration die to have them regain an additional amount of hit points. The bonus equals the number you roll on the Bardic Inspiration. A creature that receives this bonus gains a bonus to their next attack roll, ability check, or saving throw they make until the start of your next turn equal to the number rolled on the inspiration die.

subclassFeature.name: Shelter of The Travelers
entries: Starting at 6th level, you learn the {@spell Leomund's tiny hut} spell, which counts as a bard spell for you but doesn’t count against your total number of known spells, and you can cast it once without expending a spell slot or requiring material components. When you cast the spell using this feature, the dome created covers a 20-foot radius instead, allowing more than 9 medium or smaller creatures to fit inside the radius, and you can enter and exit the hut as you please without ending the spell.

The hut itself, and creatures inside of the hut, are {@condition invisible} for the duration of the spell. As an action, you can allow the hut and the creatures inside of the hut to be seen, or you can use another action to hide the hut and the creatures inside.
You regain the ability to cast the spell in this way again when you finish a long rest, or if you expend a spell slot of 3rd level or higher to regain the ability to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Minstrel's Duet
entries: At 14th level, when you restore hit points to another creature using a spell of 1st-level or higher, you regain hit points equal to two rolls of your bardic inspiration die.
Whenever you use Minstrel's Melody, you can roll a {@dice d6} and use it instead of expending a Bardic Inspiration die.

subclassFeature.name: Minstrel's Inspiration
entries: Also at 14th level, a creature with one of your bardic inspiration regains a number of hit points at the start of each of their turns equal to one roll of your bardic inspiration die. They also regain hit points when they use their bardic inspiration equal to the number rolled on the inspiration die.

subclassFeature.name: College of The Songblade
entries: In more ancient times, a group of elves created an order of bards which banded together when evil threatened the Arda Kingdom. These bards would empower their weapons with the power of their voice and songs, similar to another order of elf wizards. Unlike that order, this one was open with other races learning the secrets behind this power, opening up this bard college to all who wished to learn.
In modern days, this college is taught more for fun and sport. However, some of the eldest of elves are among those who founded the college, and they still know of its true purpose to thwart evil.

subclassFeature.name: Bond of The Songblade
entries: Starting at 3rd level when you choose this college, choose one type of weapon to become your Songblade from the following: dagger, longsword, rapier, or shortsword.

When you are wielding a Songblade, you can use Charisma for its attack and damage rolls instead of Strength or Dexterity. In addition, it counts as a spellcasting focus for you and you can cast spells using somatic components even if both hands are occupied, so long as your Songblade is being held in one of them.
While holding your Songblade, you gain a bonus to your AC equal to your Charisma modifier provided you are not wearing medium or heavy armor.
You can change which type of weapon your Songblade is when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Song of Love and War
entries: Also at 3rd level, when you cast a bard spell that requires a verbal component, you can spend a bardic inspiration die and roll it, adding the result to one of the damage or healing rolls.

Alternatively, when you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack using a Songblade, you can expend one spell slot to deal psychic damage to the target, in addition to the weapon's damage. The extra damage is one roll of your bardic inspiration die for a 1st-level spell slot, plus another bardic inspiration die for each spell level higher than 1st, to a maximum of 3 inspiration dice.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Also at 6th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. Moreover, you can cast one of your cantrips in place of one of those attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Song of Heroism
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you use your Countercharm feature, you can give each affected creature, including yourself, temporary hit points equal to your Bard level. At the start of each of their turns while your Countercharm is active, they gain temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus provided they did not have more temporary hit points remaining.

subclassFeature.name: Continuous Song
entries: Starting at 14th level, whenever you use your Song of Love and War feature, you can roll a d6 and use it instead of expending a Bardic Inspiration die.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Charity
entries: The oath of charity binds a paladin to the greatest ideals of sacrifice, good will, giving to those in need, and protecting those who need aid. These are warriors who focus their efforts on healing just as much as they do fighting. They hold themselves to never give in to selfish desires, to offer a healing hand to the injured, and to give to those who will not just take.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of Charity
entries: {@i Though the exact words and strictures of the Oath of Charity vary, paladins of this oath share these tenets.}

entries.name: Charity
entries: Give to the poor, especially when you have plenty to make do with.

entries.name: Sacrifice
entries: Always be willing to pay the ultimate price for the benefit of others.

entries.name: Tempered
entries: Stay true to your emotions, but never let them consume you.

entries.name: Heal and Protect
entries: Heal the weakened innocents, and ensure they are not harmed again.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed.

entries.caption: Oath of Charity Spells
rows: {@spell create food and water}, {@spell life transference|XGE}

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Mend the Wounded
entries: You can hasten your efforts to heal a wounded creature using your channel divinity. For the next minute, you can use your Lay on Hands feature as a bonus action rather than an action. Also for the duration, when you restore hit points to a creature using a spell of 1st level or higher, you can add a bonus to the roll equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Protect the Weak
entries: You can use your channel divinity to protect an ally from the jaws of defeat. When a creature you can see within 60 feet of you would be reduced to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction to have them be reduced to 1 hit point instead.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Regeneration
entries: Starting at 7th level, you can keep others alive when they are struggling through the midst of battle. When a creature (other than yourself) with less than half of their maximum hit points starts their turn within 10 feet of you, they regain a number of hit points equal to your Charisma modifier.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Shield the Wounded
entries: At 15th level, you can use a bonus action to choose a creature you can see within 60 feet of you that doesn’t have all of their hit points. Until the start of your next turn, creatures have disadvantage on attack rolls against the chosen creature.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Giver of Life
entries: At 20th level you can channel your divine power to invoke powerful healing abilities. As a bonus action, you gain the following benefits for 1 minute:

items: When you would normally roll one or more dice to restore hit points with a spell, you instead use the highest number possible for each die.
When you cast a spell that restores hit points using a 1st-level spell slot or higher, the spell is treated as if it were one level higher than the expended slot.
If a creature within 30 feet of you fails a saving throw, you can spend your reaction and a 1st-level or higher spell slot to have them re-roll. They must use the new result.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest, unless you expend a 5th-level spell slot to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of The Truth Seeker
entries: This oath is taken by paladins who do not know who or what they want to be. Their paths everchanging, but their choices are always theirs to make. By binding themselves to this oath, a paladin swears that through their travels they will find themselves and forge their own destinies, as well as the destinies of others.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of The Truth Seeker
entries: {@i Though the exact words and strictures of the Oath of The Truth Seeker vary, paladins of this oath share these tenets.}

entries.name: Truth
entries: Stay true to yourself, let yourself be free of the fear of judgment and always seek the truth.

entries.name: Destiny
entries: Everyone has their own path, but it’s up to you to forge your destiny.

entries.name: Guide The Lost
entries: As you aim to follow your own path, always lend a helping hand to those who are lost themselves.

entries.name: Confidence
entries: Douse the flames of doubt, believe in yourself and those around you.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed.

entries.caption: Oath of The Truth Seeker Spells

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Traveler's Step
entries: By using your channel divinity you can empower your ability to move and allow yourself to step between planes momentarily. For the next minute, as a bonus action on your turn you can teleport to an unoccupied space within 30 feet of you. You do not have to see the space in order to teleport there.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Reveal the Truth
entries: You can use your channel divinity to peer into a creature's truths. If you have been speaking to a creature for at least a minute, you can use your channel divinity to force that creature to make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, you learn their alignment and whether or not they are speaking truthfully. You also learn that creature's type and whether or not their current form is their true form.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Truth
entries: Starting at 7th level, you emanate an aura of revealing truths. You and your allies gain a bonus to Wisdom (Insight) and Intelligence (Investigation) checks equal to your Charisma modifier  (with a minimum bonus of +1), provided you are not incapacitated.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Guiding Sword
entries: At 15th level, being unable to see a creature does not impose disadvantage on your attack rolls, nor does it give them advantage on attack rolls against you. In battle, you can always determine which direction a hostile creature is in if they have made an attack against you or one of your allies in your Aura of Truth within the past minute.

subclassFeature.name: Champion of Truth
entries: At 20th level you can channel your divine power to invoke powerful abilities. As a bonus action, you gain the following benefits for 1 minute:

items: Your movement speed is doubled and you can make one additional weapon attack when you take the attack action.
You can always determine whether a creature is lying. When you use this feature, you can retain this benefit for up to 1 hour past the duration.
Each time a hostile creature hits you with an attack or casts a spell on you, they must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, they take 2d10 psychic damage.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest, unless you expend a 5th-level spell slot to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Knight
entries: Choosing a darker path, you've stripped your morality and humanity to enhance your martial prowess. Harnessing blood magic and enhancing your fighting style further with these dark arts.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in one of the following skills of your choice: Arcana, Insight, Medicine, or Religion.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomancy
entries: {@i 3rd-level Blood Knight feature}

Studying occult-based magic, you’ve learned the very nature of blood magic and can use it yourself to a limited degree. Your blood magic will be represented by hemomancy dice. These dice are d4s and you have a number of hemomancy dice equal to twice your proficiency bonus.

You use these dice to fuel your blood magic abilities, and you regain all of your hemomancy dice after a long rest. You cannot gain more hemomancy dice than you can have at your current level in this way. If a hemomancy feature requires a creature to make a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier.

When you use a Hemomancy die, regardless if it is spent or not, you roll the die and take damage equal to what you roll. Your hemomancy dice grows stronger with you as you gain levels in this class, becoming a d6 at 7th level, a d8 at 10th level, a d10 at 15th level, and a d12 at 18th level.
You can use your hemomancy dice in the following ways:

entries.name: Blood-Boosted Accuracy
entries: Whenever you would miss with a weapon attack, you can use a hemomancy die and add a bonus to the roll equal to what you rolled, potentially turning the attack into a hit. If it hits, you deal a number of necrotic damage equal to what you rolled to that creature. You spend the hemomancy die only if the attack hits.

entries.name: Blood Bursting Strike
entries: Whenever you deal damage with a weapon, you can expend a hemomancy die and roll it, adding a number of necrotic damage equal to the number rolled and then that creature makes a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature has disadvantage on attack rolls until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Forge
entries: {@i 3rd-level Blood Knight feature}

You have the innate ability to morph your blood into volatile weapons and ammunition. As a bonus action, you can create either a blood weapon or blood ammunition. You can use this feature once per long rest, or you can spend a hemomancy die to use it again. The created weapon or pieces of ammunition lasts for 1 hour, or a number of hours equal to the damage you took from the hemomancy die.

entries.name: Blood Weapon
entries: You conjure a red glass-like magical melee weapon with the finesse and thrown properties. When you throw it, it has a range of 60 feet and no long range. When thrown, it magically reappears in your hand after it hits or misses a target. It deals necrotic damage on hit equal to your hemomancy die.

entries.name: Blood Ammunition
entries: You conjure 10 pieces of red glass-like ammunition. It can take any form of ammunition, so long as it can be used by a ranged weapon. Using these pieces of ammunition changes the damage type of your ranged weapon to necrotic and you can choose to replace the damage die with your hemomancy die.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Bath
entries: {@i 7th-level Blood Knight feature}

You can push your body to its absolute limit to unleash a dark power from within using a combination of the power of your will and your rage. You can spend a hemomancy die to enter a blood bath. As a bonus action, you magically gain the following benefits, which last for 1 minute:

items: Whenever you deal damage using a weapon, you can deal an additional amount of damage equal to your proficiency bonus. The damage dealt is of the weapon’s damage type.
You can forgo one of your extra attacks to gain advantage on all of your weapon attacks for the rest of this turn.
Whenever you take damage, except from your hemomancy dice, once per round you can reduce that damage by half using your reaction.
As a bonus action, and part of the bonus action used to enter your blood bath, you can make one weapon attack using a blood weapon.

entries: During your Blood Bath, each time you hit with a weapon attack you lose 1 hit point. Your blood bath ends early if you are reduced to 0 hit points, incapacitated, or die. You can use your blood bath once, regaining the ability to use it again when you complete a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Reserves
entries: {@i 10th-level Blood Knight feature}

Whenever you use your Second Wind feature while your Blood Bath is active, you can add an additional amount of healing equal to your hemomancy die as you draw upon even greater reserves of power from your blood magic. This expends a Hemomancy Die but does not deal damage to yourself for using it.

In addition, as a bonus action you can deal damage to yourself equal to your hemomancy die and regain a spent hemomancy die. You can do so once, regaining the ability to do so when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomatic Bulwark
entries: {@i 15th-level Blood Knight feature}
The following options are added to your Hemomancy feature:

entries.name: Blood Barrier
entries: As a reaction whenever you would be hit by an attack, you can spend a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to your AC until the start of your next turn, potentially turning the attack into a miss.

entries.name: Blood-Boosted Ability
entries: Whenever you make an ability check or saving throw that uses Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution, you may use a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to the d20, provided you are not incapacitated. You spend the hemomancy die only if the check or save was successful.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomatic Mastery
entries: {@i 18th-level Blood Knight feature}
You regain all of your spent Hemomancy Dice whenever you finish a short or long rest. In addition, the following options are added to your Hemomancy feature:

entries.name: Blood Curse
entries: As an action, you can spend a hemomancy die to magically curse a creature within 60 feet of you that you can see. That creature becomes overwhelmed and cursed by your blood magic for 1 minute. That creature becomes vulnerable to necrotic damage and gains no benefits from having resistance to necrotic damage. A creature makes a Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. A creature is immune to this effect if it is a plant, undead, or construct, or if it is immune to necrotic damage. You can only have one creature affected by your blood curse at a time. A remove curse can also remove these effects.

entries.name: Bloody End
entries: When you reduce a creature to 0 hit points, as a reaction you can absorb part of its life force into your own body to fuel your vitality. You can spend a hemomancy die and roll it, gaining a number of temporary hit points equal to what you rolled plus your Constitution modifier. You do not take damage when you spend a hemomancy die in this way.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Sorcery
entries: Blood magic is often used by worshipers of evil gods, demons, or arch devils. Rarely though, some are born to be a blood mage through demonic or devilish origins. Tieflings are strong candidates for becoming blood mages, but anyone of any racial origin has the potential for it. A blood mage is often seen as a sign of some powerful demon or devil seeping into the material plane and killing a blood mage is often associated with keeping said demon or devil in their respective planes. As such, natural born blood mages are hunted and killed.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Magic
entries: {@i 1st-level Sanguine feature}

Your magic comes from the demonic abyss, the infernal nine hells, or even from powerful witches. You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Blood Magic Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be an {@filter enchantment or necromancy spell from the sorcerer, warlock, or wizard spell list|spells|class=sorcerer;warlock;wizard|school=E,N|level=1;2;3;4;5} or a spell with the hemomancy subschool can be learned regardless of the class or school of magic.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomancy
entries: {@i 1st-level Sanguine feature}

Studying occult-based magic, you’ve learned the very nature of blood magic and can use it yourself to a limited degree. Your blood magic will be represented by hemomancy dice. These dice are d4s and you have a number of hemomancy dice equal to twice your proficiency bonus.

You use these dice to fuel your blood magic abilities, and you regain all of your hemomancy dice after a long rest. You cannot gain more hemomancy dice than you can have at your current level in this way. If a hemomancy feature requires a creature to make a saving throw, the DC equals your Spell Save DC.

When you use a Hemomancy die, regardless if it is spent or not, you roll the die and take damage equal to what you roll. Your hemomancy dice grows stronger with you as you gain levels in this class, becoming a d6 at 5th level, a d8 at 9th level, a d10 at 13th level, and a d12 at 17th level.
You can use your hemomancy dice in the following ways:

entries.name: Blood-Homing Spell
entries: When you make a spell attack you can use a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to the attack roll. If it hits, you deal an additional amount of necrotic damage equal to the number rolled. You spend the hemomancy die only if you hit.

entries.name: Blood-Bursting Magic
entries: When you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, you can spend a hemomancy die to release outward a burst of necromantic energy. Each creature of your choice within 10 feet of you takes necrotic damage equal to the number rolled on the hemomancy die plus your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Bolstering Magic
entries: {@i 6th-level Sanguine feature}

Your innate blood magic allows you to manipulate your spells more efficiently. When you use a metamagic option that would ordinarily spend sorcery points, you can choose to spend hemomancy dice for every sorcery point that would have been used. You still roll the hemomancy dice and take damage equal to what you roll as normal.

Also, you can use a bonus action to spend a sorcery point to regain a spent hemomancy die. You can use this bonus action a number times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Resistance
entries: {@i 6th-level Sanguine feature}
You have resistance to poison and necrotic damage and you have advantage on saving throws made to resist being poisoned or diseased.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Magic
entries: {@i 14th-level Sanguine feature}

During short moments of respite you can regain some of your lost sorcerous power. When you finish a short rest, you can spend a hit die to regain sorcery points equal to the number rolled. You can only spend a hit die in this way once, regaining the ability to do so again when you complete a long rest.
In addition, the following options are added to your Hemomancy feature:

entries.name: Sanguine Spell
entries: Your blood magic can be used to empower your magic further. When you make an ability check for a spell you cast, you can roll a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to the d20. You spend the hemomancy die only if the check is successful.

entries.name: Blood Concentrate
entries: When your body fails your magic, you can draw on power to endure further. When you would drop concentration on a spell, you can spend a hemomancy die to maintain that concentration. The damage you take from this ability does not break concentration on said spell.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Transformation
entries: {@i 18th-level Sanguine feature}
Your mastery over blood magic has further changed your body permanently, granting you immunity to necrotic damage and immunity to being diseased.

In addition, you can undergo a more powerful transformation which furthers your mastery over said magic. You learn the spell {@spell Guise of the Blood Witch|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting} and it counts as a sorcerer spell for you but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. You can cast the spell without requiring material components and you can cast it without expending a spell slot by spending 6 hemomancy dice instead. You can cast the spell in this way once, regaining the ability to do so again when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Nature Child
entries: You have a unique bond with nature that allows you to innately call on its magic. Whether you were a magical phenomenon or perhaps you were born into a family of druids, your connection to the weave, the material world, and the primordial elements are all interconnected.

subclassFeature.name: Nature Magic
entries: Your link to nature allows you to learn spells from the druid class. When your Spellcasting feature lets you learn or replace a sorcerer cantrip or a sorcerer spell of 1st level or higher, you can choose the new spell from the druid spell list or the sorcerer spell list. You must otherwise obey all the restrictions for selecting the spell, and it becomes a sorcerer spell for you.

In addition, choose a terrain for the source of your origins: forest, tundra, desert, coast, or mountain. You learn additional spells based on that terrain and your level in this class, as shown below. They are sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of sorcerer spells known. If you later replace any of these  spells, you must replace it with a spell from the druid spell list.

subclassFeature.name: Nature's Grace
entries: Starting at 1st level, when you cast one of the spells granted to you by your Nature Magic feature, you gain {@dice 2d4} + your proficiency bonus temporary hit points.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Remedies
entries: At 6th level, you can call on your innate connection to nature to heal your allies. As a bonus action, you can spend any number of sorcery points up to your proficiency bonus and have one creature you can see within 60 feet of you (you can choose yourself) regain {@dice 1d6} hit points per sorcery point spent. You add your Charisma modifier to the total. This healing has no effect on undead or constructs.

subclassFeature.name: Natural Form
entries: At 14th level, you can summon your magic to allow yourself to transform into your true nature. As a bonus action, you gain the following benefits for 1 minute, or until you end the form as a bonus action.

items: Your AC equals 13 + your Dexterity modifier.

You have natural weapons which are unarmed strikes which count as simple weapons. They deal {@dice 2d8} slashing, piercing, or bludgeoning damage on hit (you choose when you attack). You can add your Charisma modifier to the attack and damage rolls instead of Strength.
You gain temporary hit points equal to twice your sorcerer level.

You gain one of the improvements: a flying speed of 30 feet, a climbing speed of 60 feet, a swimming speed of 60 feet and the ability to breathe underwater as you do air, or a burrow speed of 30 feet and tremorsense out to a range of 60 feet.
You ignore difficult terrain.

entries: Once you've transformed, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest or if you have no remaining uses, you can spend 5 sorcery points to transform again.
You choose what your form looks like, but typically it resembles a bestial or plant-like appearance associated with your terrain origin.

subclassFeature.name: Natural Evolution
entries: Starting at 18th level, your body has permanently changed. When you finish a long rest, choose one of the benefits listed in your Natural Form feature, you gain that improvement until you next finish a long rest. After which you can either choose another improvement or the same one to gain again.

subclassFeature.name: School of Blood Magic
entries: Shrouded by curiosity and insidious methods, you have sacrificed a portion of your mortality to gain greater arcane power. You’ll do anything to get an edge over your opponents, even at the cost of your own strength.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: {@i 2nd-level Blood Magic feature}
You gain proficiency in either intimidation or religion.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomancy
entries: {@i 2nd-level Blood Magic feature}

Studying occult-based magic, you’ve learned the very nature of blood magic and can use it yourself to a limited degree. Your blood magic will be represented by hemomancy dice. These dice are d4s and you have a number of hemomancy dice equal to twice your proficiency bonus.

You use these dice to fuel your blood magic abilities, and you regain all of your hemomancy dice after a long rest. You cannot gain more hemomancy dice than you can have at your current level in this way. If a hemomancy feature requires a creature to make a saving throw, the DC equals your Spell Save DC.

When you use a Hemomancy die, regardless if it is spent or not, you roll the die and take damage equal to what you roll. Your hemomancy dice grows stronger with you as you gain levels in this class, becoming a d6 at 6th level, a d8 at 9th level, a d10 at 14th level, and a d12 at 17th level.
You can use your hemomancy dice in the following ways:

entries.name: Blood Drenched Mind
entries: When you make an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw that uses intelligence, you can use a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to the check. You spend the hemomancy die only if the check is successful.

entries.name: Blood Soaked Spell
entries: When you cast a spell of 1st level or higher that deals damage, you can spend a hemomancy die and add the number rolled to one of the damage rolls of the spell.

entries.name: Blood Focus
entries: As a bonus action, you can use a hemomancy die to empower an arcane focus or a component pouch for 1 hour. When you do, you can treat that arcane focus for the component cost of spells with costly components, up to a maximum component cost of 50 gp x the number rolled on the hemomancy die. If you use it for a spell that consumes the material component, the empowerment ends early. The first time you use this ability before you finish a long rest you do not spend the hemomancy die, every time after the first until you complete a long rest you spend it.

subclassFeature.name: Dark Devotion
entries: {@i 6th-level Blood Magic feature}
Your devotion to the dark arts of blood magic gives you a will stronger than most. You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed or frightened.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Savant
entries: {@i 6th-level Blood Magic feature}
As a bonus action you can spend a spell slot of any level to regain a number of spent hemomancy dice equal to the slot’s level. You cannot gain more hemomancy dice than the maximum you can have.

subclassFeature.name: Sigils of the Blood Arcane
entries: {@i 10th-level Blood Magic feature}

You’ve discovered an arcane sigil that allows you to learn new blood magic spells. Choose two spells from the cleric, warlock, or wizard classes. A spell you choose must be of a level you can cast, as shown on the Wizard table, or a cantrip. Each spell is represented by an arcane sigil, which appears in your spell book. These spells are always prepared and count as wizard spells for you. You choose one additional spell at 14th level, and one more at 17th level.
Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of those spells with another one from the same listed spell lists.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Magic Mastery
entries: {@i 14th-level Blood Magic feature}

You can cast the spells chosen from your Sigils of the Blood Arcane feature with expending a spell slot by spending a number a hemomancy dice equal to the spell’s level. When you cast one of these spells in this way, you must cast it at its lowest level and you cannot cast that spell in this way again until you finish a long rest.
In addition, the following options are added to your Hemomancy feature:

entries.name: Bleeding Spell
entries: Whenever you deal damage with a spell, you can use a hemomancy die (no action required) and force that creature to make a constitution saving throw. On a failed save, for a number of rounds equal to the number rolled on the hemomancy die they take damage at the start of each of their turns equal to one roll of your hemomancy die. Rolling the hemomancy die in that way does not deal damage to yourself. The type of damage they take is the damage type of the spell. On a successful save, they do not take damage at the start of their turns. You spend the hemomancy die only if they failed their save.

entries.name: Blood Invocation
entries: When you begin casting a spell, you can replace one or more of the components required for the spell by spending a hemomancy die for each component replaced. If you replace a material component for the spell, the material must not require to be consumed and must have a maximum cost of 500 gp, otherwise it cannot be replaced with a hemomancy die.
