subclassFeature.name: The Blood Witch
entries: Said to be the first to unlock this ancient form of fiendish magic, The Blood Witch is a very mysterious entity with a sort of mastery over blood magic. Where she acquired it from exactly is still unknown, as are many things about her. Some that have met her have claimed her to be a deity, while others refer to her as a false god with an exaggerated ego. She is revered by cultists as the first and one true master of the blood arts, while many see her as a stepping stone into their own wicked ascension.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: {@i 1st-level The Blood Witch feature}
The Blood Witch lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Hemomancy
entries: {@i 1st-level The Blood Witch feature}

Studying occult-based magic, you’ve learned the very nature of blood magic and can use it yourself to a limited degree. Your blood magic will be represented by hemomancy dice. These dice are d4s and you have a number of hemomancy dice equal to twice your proficiency bonus.

You use these dice to fuel your blood magic abilities, and you regain all of your hemomancy dice after a long rest. You cannot gain more hemomancy dice than you can have at your current level in this way. If a hemomancy feature requires a creature to make a saving throw, the DC equals your Spell Save DC.

When you use a Hemomancy die, regardless if it is spent or not, you roll the die and take damage equal to what you roll. Your hemomancy dice grows stronger with you as you gain levels in this class, becoming a d6 at 5th level, a d8 at 9th level, a d10 at 13th level, and a d12 at 17th level.
You can use your hemomancy dice in the following ways:

entries.name: Hex of the Witch
entries: As a bonus action, you can spend a hemomancy die to magically curse a creature you can see within 60 feet of you. When you do, that creature cannot regain hit points for a number of rounds equal to the number rolled. At the start of each of the affected creature’s turns, it takes necrotic damage equal to your hemomancy die. You concentrate on this hex as if you were concentrating on a spell.

entries.name: Blood Transmutation
entries: When you cast a cantrip that deals damage, you can use a hemomancy die to convert the damage type of the cantrip into necrotic damage until the end of the current turn and one damage roll receives an additional amount of necrotic damage equal to the number rolled on the hemomancy die. The first time you use this ability after each long rest, you don't expend the hemomancy die. All other times you use the ability, you expend the die.

subclassFeature.name: Eyes of The Blood Witch
entries: {@i 1st-level The Blood Witch feature}

The Blood Witch was said to have a special sense that allowed her to find hidden paths and secret doors. As an action, you can inherit this magical sense for 1 minute. While you have this magical sight, you can potentially see through illusions and {@condition invisible} creatures and objects as if they weren’t invisible.

This magical sight is limited however, as it is only a portion of The Blood Witch’s true sight. In order to see an {@condition invisible} creature or object, you must pass a Wisdom (Perception) check in order to properly see it. If the creature was hidden, then the DC is the Dexterity (Stealth) check it made, or if it wasn’t hidden the DC is 5 + the CR of the creature. If the object is {@condition invisible}, the DC equals the AC of the object or if it does not have an AC, the DM determines the check based on the size or difficulty to see the object in question.  If the invisibility was created via a spell, such as {@spell Invisibility|PHB}, the DC equals the Spell Save DC of the caster.

To see through an illusion depends on the illusion itself. If the illusion is a spell, such as {@spell Disguise Self|PHB}, the DC equals the Spell Save DC of the caster of the spell. If the illusion is made via other means, the DM determines the DC based on the circumstances of the illusion.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
{@i Note: A transmutation spell, such as Polymorph, is not merely an illusion but an actual transformation and you cannot see its true form in the current state of this ability.}

subclassFeature.name: Improved Witch's Sight
entries: {@i 6th-level The Blood Witch feature}

As an action, you can spend a use of your Eyes of The Blood Witch feature to instead cast {@spell See Invisibility|PHB} without expending a spell slot or requiring material components. When cast in this way, the spell instead lasts for a minute instead of an hour.

subclassFeature.name: Sacrificial Spells
entries: {@i 10th-level The Blood Witch feature}

Using your blood magic, you can cast spells using your own vitality rather than through your pact magic. When you cast a warlock spell, instead of spending a spell slot you can instead spend a number of hemomancy dice equal to the level you cast the spell. You can cast the spell at its original level, or to a maximum level equal to your Warlock Spell Slot. The damage you take from your hemomancy dice when spent in this way is doubled.

subclassFeature.name: Emissary of The Blood Witch
entries: {@i 14th-level The Blood Witch feature}

The first time you use your Eyes of The Blood Witch feature, you instead cast the {@spell True Seeing|PHB} spell without expending a spell slot or requiring material components, but you can only target yourself. It lasts for its full duration and cannot be dispelled. Once you reach 15th level, you also gain the {@optfeature Witch Sight|PHB} Eldritch Invocation, but it does not count against your total number of Eldritch Invocations.
In addition, the following options are added to your Hemomancy feature:

entries.name: Potent Blood Magic
entries: When you cast a spell using a Warlock spell slot, you can spend a hemomancy die to force every creature affected by the spell to take necrotic damage equal to the number rolled plus your charisma modifier.

entries.name: Blood Magic Reserves
entries: When you have no remaining hemomancy dice, as a bonus action you can spend a warlock spell slot to regain 5 hemomancy dice. You can use the ability twice, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: The Matron of Ravens
entries: A mortal who ascended to divinity, the mother of ravens and the queen of life and death. Your patron is the Matron of Ravens, a mysterious being who rules the Shadowfell from a palace of ice deep within that dread realm. The Matron of Ravens watches over the world, anticipating each creature's death and ensuring that it meets its end at the proscribed time and place. As the ruler of the Shadowfell, she dwells in a decayed, dark reflection of the world. Her ability to reach into the world is limited. Thus, she turns to mortal warlocks to serve her will. Warlocks sworn to the Matron of Ravens receive visions and whispers from her in their dreams, sending them on quests and warning them of impending dangers.

The Matron of Raven's followers are expected to serve her will in the world. She concerns herself with ensuring that those fated to die pass from the world as expected, and bids her agents to defeat those who seek to cheat death through undeath or other imitations of immortality. She hates intelligent undead and expects her followers to strike them down, whereas mindless undead such as skeletons and zombies are little more than stumbling automatons in her eyes.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Matron of Ravens lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Eyes of The Raven
entries: At 1st level, you gain the ability to sense the presence of the undead, whose existence is an insult to the natural cycle of life. You always know the location of any undead within 30 feet of you that isn't behind total cover and that isn't protected from divination magic. This sense doesn't tell you anything about a creature's capabilities or identity.

As an action you can extend the range of this special sense to 60 feet until the start of your next turn. You can do so a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
In addition, you gain darkvision out to a range of 60 feet. If you already have darkvision from your race, its range increases by 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Visage of Ravens
entries: Also at 1st level, you can manifest an aspect of your patron's dreadful power. As a bonus action, you transform for 1 minute. You gain the following benefits while transformed:

items: You have resistance to cold and necrotic damage.

When you deal damage with an attack or spell, you can add an amount of necrotic damage equal to your proficiency bonus to one of the damage rolls. This necrotic damage becomes twice as potent against undead, and ignores any resistance or immunities to necrotic. You can deal this extra damage once per turn.
You gain temporary hit points equal to {@dice 1d10} + your warlock level.

entries: You can transform a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

The appearance of your Visage of Ravens reflects some aspect of your patron. For example, your form could be a shroud of shadows forming the mask and robes of your patron, or shadowy ravens might fly around you and merge with your attacks and spells.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Raven Form
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you transform into your Visage of Ravens, you gain the following benefits until the form expires.

items: You gain a flying speed equal to twice your walking speed and can hover.
You are immune to being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.
Undead that start their turn within 30 feet of you takes {@dice 1d10} force damage.

subclassFeature.name: Raven-Touched
entries: Starting at 10th level, you've been granted a gift by your patron, allowing you to pursue her will further. You no longer need to eat, drink, or breathe.
In addition, when you transform into your Visage of Ravens, you have immunity to cold and necrotic damage rather than resistance.

subclassFeature.name: Sunder Undeath
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can call on the powers of your patron to sunder and repel undead. As an action, you can emit an aura that extends out to a radius of 15 feet centered on yourself. Undead cannot willingly enter the aura nor reach through it. Undead that start their turn in the aura gains vulnerability to all damage and their movement speed is reduced to 0 until they are no longer within the aura. You can use an action to extend this aura out to a range of 30 feet until the end of your next turn.

The aura lasts for 1 minute, or until you dismiss it as a bonus action. You concentrate on this effect as you would a spell. You can call on this aura once, regaining the ability to do so again when you finish a long rest, or when you have no remaining uses you can expend a warlock spell slot to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Four Elements
entries: You follow a monastic tradition that teaches you to harness the elements. When you focus your ki, you can align yourself with the forces of creation and bend the four elements to your will, using them as an extension of your body. Some members of this tradition dedicate themselves to a single element, but others weave the elements together.
Many monks of this tradition tattoo their bodies with representations of their ki powers, commonly imagined as coiling dragons, but also as phoenixes, fish, plants, mountains, and cresting waves.

subclassFeature.name: Disciple of the Elements
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn magical disciplines that harness the power of the four elements. A discipline requires you to spend ki points each time you use it.
You know the Elemental Attunement discipline and two other elemental disciplines of your choice. You learn one additional elemental discipline of your choice at 6th, 11th, and 17th level.
Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can also replace one elemental discipline that you already know with a different discipline.

entries.name: Casting Elemental Spells
entries: Some elemental disciplines allow you to cast spells. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} of the Player's Handbook for the general rules of spellcasting. To cast one of these spells, you use its casting time and other rules, but you don't need to provide material components for it.

Once you reach 5th level in this class, you can spend additional ki points to increase the level of an elemental discipline spell that you cast, provided that the spell has an enhanced effect at a higher level, as {@spell burning hands} does. The spell's level increases by 1 for each additional ki point you spend. For example, if you are a 5th-level monk and use Sweeping Cinder Strike to cast {@spell burning hands}, you can spend 3 ki points to cast it as a 2nd-level spell (the discipline's base cost of 2 ki points plus 1).

The maximum number of ki points you can spend to cast a spell in this way (including its base ki point cost and any additional ki points you spend to increase its level) is determined by your monk level, as shown in the Spells and Ki Points table. At 5th level, you may spend up to 3 ki points; this increases to 4 ki points at 9th level, 5 at 13th level, and 6 at 17th level.

entries.caption: Spells and Ki Points
colLabels: Maximum Ki Points for a Spell

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Form
entries: Also at 3rd level when you take the attack action, you can choose to enter an elemental form, which lasts for 1 minute, by spending a ki point. When you enter an elemental form, choose either Air, Earth, Fire, or Water. You gain one of the following benefits while your Elemental Form is active:

entries.name: Air
entries: Light like a feather, a leaf on the wind. Your reach for your melee attacks using unarmed strikes or monk weapons is increased by 5 feet and you can use your Wisdom score in place of your Strength when determining how far or how high you can jump.

entries.name: Earth
entries: Stubborn like stone and unmoving like boulders. You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical attacks and have advantage on ability checks and saving throws made to resist being pushed back or knocked {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Fire
entries: Power erupts from your body and is focused onto your fists and weapons. Your unarmed strikes and monk weapons deal fire damage instead of its normal damage type. In addition, you have resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: Water
entries: You are unfettered by the oceanic tides. While your feet are submerged in water, your movement speed is increased by 10 feet and swimming does not cost you any additional movement. In addition you have resistance to cold damage.

In addition to these benefits, while your chosen Elemental Form is active, disciplines that associate with said element costs 1 less ki for the initial cost of the discipline, to a minimum cost of 1 ki point. For example, while your Elemental Form is active and you are using your Fire Form and you use Sweeping Cinder Strike to cast {@spell burning hands}, you can spend 1 ki point instead of its base cost of 2.
You can only have the benefits of one chosen element at any given time, however you can change the benefits of your Elemental Form when you take the attack action by spending an additional ki point.

Your elemental form requires concentration which acts as if you were concentrating on a spell. If an elemental discipline casts a spell that requires concentration, you maintain concentration on both that spell and your elemental form. Losing concentration on either one breaks concentration on the other.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Disciplines
entries: The elemental disciplines are presented in alphabetical order. If a discipline requires a level, you must be the level in this class to learn the discipline.

entries.name: Breathtaking Dance (20th Level Required)
entries: You can spend 6 ki points to cast {@spell suffocating sphere|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

entries.name: Clench of the North Wind (6th Level Required)
Dance of Fiery Dragons (20th level required)
entries: You can spend 6 ki points to cast {@spell fire storm}.

entries.name: Flames of the Phoenix (11th Level Required)
Gong of the Summit (6th Level Required)
Direct the Thunderstorm (11th Level Required)
entries: You can spend 4 ki points to cast {@spell lightning bolt}.

entries.name: Ride the Waves (6th Level Required)
entries: You can spend 3 ki to cast {@spell slipstream|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

entries.name: River of Hungry Flame (17th Level Required)
Rolling Stone (6th Level Required)
entries: You can spend 3 ki to cast {@spell boulder bash|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

entries.name: Slapping Waves
entries: You can spend 2 ki to cast {@spell water whack|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

entries.name: Step of Giants
entries: You can spend 2 ki to cast {@spell thunderstomp|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

entries.name: Waterfall of the Elders (6th Level Required)
entries: You can spend 3 ki to cast {@spell whelm|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

entries.name: Wave of Rolling Earth (17th Level Required)
Whirlwind Ballet (11th Level Required)
entries: You can spend 4 ki to cast {@spell cyclone|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Elemental Discipline
entries: You learn one additional elemental discipline of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Focus
entries: At 6th level, you’ve put focus and practice into one particular element. When you finish a long rest, choose either Air, Earth, Fire, or Water. Depending on your choice, you gain one of the following benefits which ends the next time you finish a long rest and you can choose a different benefit or regain the one that ended:

entries.name: Air
entries: Your body becomes unfettered by the ground beneath your feet. You gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed and can hover, however if you end your turn airborne you slowly descend 60 feet and either safely touch the ground or end your turn falling.

entries.name: Earth
entries: Attuned to the earth beneath you, you’ve hardened your body to be sturdier. Your current and maximum hit points are increased by an amount equal to your Monk level.

entries.name: Fire
entries: Flames burn from within your soul and allow you to turn your foes to ash. Once per turn, when you hit with an unarmed strike or monk weapon you can add an additional amount of fire damage equal to your martial arts die.

entries.name: Water
entries: Fluid like the river, your movements through water are effortless and your body adapts to underwater environments. You have a swimming speed equal to your walking speed and can breathe underwater as you do air. In addition, as a bonus action you can use extreme focus to stand perfectly still on water not falling through it as you normally would. This extreme focus ends when you take damage or when you move.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Elemental Discipline
entries: You learn one additional elemental discipline of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Elementalist
entries: At 11th level, you’ve heightened your control over the elements granting you unique abilities depending on your Elemental Focus. While your Elemental Focus is active, you can cast one of the following spells without requiring material components or spending a spell slot or kit points depending on which element you chose:

subclassFeature.name: Extra Elemental Discipline
entries: You learn one additional elemental discipline of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Master of The Elements
entries: At 17th level you’ve attained absolute mastery over your elemental techniques. Choose one of your Elemental Disciplines. You can use that discipline as if you spent the minimum required ki point cost without expending any ki.
In addition, while your Elemental Focus is active you gain one of the following benefits depending on the element you chose:

entries.name: Air
entries: When you take the attack action using a monk weapon or unarmed strike, you can use the shove action as part of the attack action. In addition, you no longer descend at the end of your turn while flying.

entries.name: Earth
entries: Once per turn, when you take damage from an attack you can reduce that damage by an amount equal to your martial arts die.

entries.name: Fire
entries: Whenever you deal fire damage, you add a bonus to one of the damage rolls equal to your Wisdom modifier.

entries.name: Water
entries: While your feet are submerged in water your speed is doubled. In addition, you have advantage on attack rolls against a creature who does not have a swim speed while initiated in underwater combat.

In addition, you can use your action and spend 6 ki points to cast {@spell Investiture of Flame|XGE}, {@spell Investiture of Ice|XGE}, {@spell Investiture of Stone|XGE}, {@spell Investiture of Water|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting}, or {@spell Investiture of Wind|XGE}. Once you’ve cast one of these spells, you cannot cast any of these spells again until you have completed a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Soul
entries: Born with powers of primordial elders, you’ve mastered magic that revolves around the elements. The earth beneath your feet erecting from the ground in pillars of stone, the scorching hot flames wreathing off your body burning your foes, coiling water veiling you with a protective barrier, or commanding the wind around you to keep enemies at bay.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Magic
entries: Your knowledge of the elemental planes expands your magical capabilities. You learn spells at certain levels based on an associated element, as detailed on the table below. Once you gain access to one of these spells, it counts as a sorcerer spell for you and does not count towards your number of spells known.
Each of these spells can be swapped for a different elemental spell of the same type and same level by approval of your DM.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Form
entries: Also at 1st level, when you cast a spell from your Primordial Magic feature, you can instantly transform into an embodiment of the element you chose. You appear as an Elemental from that particular plane, for example if you chose Fire then your body would wreathe in flames and your eyes would glow like burning coals.

While in this primordial form, you gain a bonus to damage rolls related to your chosen element equal to your charisma modifier. Elements such as air, earth, or water are vague about what constitutes associated elements. Best rule of thumb, your DM has the final say, however air could include spells that use thunder or lightning, but not all spells. Whereas earth, water, and air can all be associated with bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing depending on the spell. Regardless, all the spells listed for your chosen element in your Primordial Magic feature will associate with your chosen element.
In addition, when you enter your primordial form you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to your sorcerer level plus your charisma modifier.
You remain in this primordial form for 1 minute and once you enter this form you cannot do so again until you finish a short or long rest.
Also, you know how to speak, read, and write Primordial.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Resistance
entries: Starting at 6th level, you gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage while your Primordial Form is active.
In addition, you always have resistance to a certain damage type based on the element you chose regardless if your primordial form is active or not:

entries.name: Air
entries: You gain resistance to thunder damage.

entries.name: Earth
entries: You gain resistance to acid damage.

entries.name: Fire
entries: You gain resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: Water
entries: You gain resistance to cold damage.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Essence
entries: Also at 6th level, when you use a metamagic option on a spell from your Primordial Magic feature, you can regain 1d6 hit points per sorcery point spent on the metamagic option for the spell. You can only gain this magical healing once a round.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Evolution
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can enter your Primordial Form as an action by spending 5 sorcery points. Your Primordial Form now lasts for an hour rather than a minute when you use it in this way. While in your Primordial Form you gain certain benefits depending on the element you chose:

entries.name: Air
entries: You have a magical flying speed of 60 feet and you can hover. In addition, you can pass through spaces as narrow as 1 inch, so long as air can pass through it.

entries.name: Earth
entries: At the start of each of your turns, so long as your feet are touching the ground, you can gain temporary hit points equal to your Charisma modifier. In addition, you have tremorsense out to a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Fire
entries: Flames erupt from your body whenever you’re in danger, scolding anyone who dares strike you. When a creature within 60 feet of you deals damage to you from an attack, they take 1d10 fire damage.

entries.name: Water
entries: You have a magical swim speed of 60 feet, can breathe underwater as you do air, and while fully submerged in water you can use a bonus action to teleport up to 60 feet to another space that is also underwater.

subclassFeature.name: Elder Elemental
entries: At 18th level, your very being permanently changes as you ascend to the peak of your elemental ancestry. You are always under the effects of your Primordial Form and can shift your appearance to appear as your natural self or your primordial self.
The temporary hit points you’d originally receive when you would enter your primordial form instead are gained after you finish a short or long rest.
In addition, the spell you gained at 1st level from your Primordial Magic feature can be cast at its lowest level without expending a spell slot or requiring material components.

subclassFeature.name: College Of The Elemental Dancer
entries: A true master of elements shifts between them, effortlessly and elegantly. As fluid with their movements as a flowing river, as hard to hit as a feather riding the wind, hits as hard as a flying rock, and as hot as flames when need be.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Dance
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can expend a use of your bardic inspiration to begin an elemental dance which lasts for 1 minute. During this time, choose a tempo from air, earth, fire, or water.  You gain one of the following benefits depending on what you chose, and you can shift your chosen element as a bonus action on subsequent turns:

entries.caption: Elemental Dance Table
rows: Your movement speed is increased by 10 feet and you can hover up to a foot off the ground effortlessly. You can cast the {@spell cutting wind|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting} cantrip, which counts as a bard spell for you.

Your body becomes tough as stone, you have resistance to non-magical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage and you can cast the {@spell magic stone|XGE} cantrip, which counts as a bard spell for you.
You can cast the {@spell fire bolt} cantrip, which counts as a bard spell for you, and your weapon attacks deal an extra amount of fire damage equal to your bardic inspiration die.

You can walk across the surface of water as you would solid ground, however you still fall through the water if you end your turn there. You can cast the {@spell water splash|TheAdventuresofTorinCampaignSetting} cantrip, which counts as a bard spell for you.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Tongue
entries: Also at 3rd level, your extensive knowledge on the elemental planes makes you an expert in conversing with said elementals. You know how to speak, read, and write Primordial. If you already have Primordial, you can instead choose a different language. In addition, you have advantage on Charisma ability checks made with elementals, provided you are not hostile toward them.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Inspiration
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can grant your elemental magic onto an ally while embracing it through your dance. While under the effects of your Elemental Dance, a creature with your bardic inspiration can use it to add to the damage rolls of their attacks or spells. The bonus damage is dependent on your current chosen tempo:

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Dance Improvement
entries: Also at 6th level, you gain some additional effects while in your Elemental Dance. While under the effects of your Elemental Dance, you gain a bonus to your AC equal to your Charisma modifier provided you aren't wearing medium or heavy armor or using a shield. In addition, you gain the ability to cast certain spells while using your bard spell slots while under the effects of your Elemental Dance depending on your chosen tempo, which count as bard spells for you:

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Ballet
entries: Starting at 14th level, your mastery over your primordial dancing has ascended to its peak. The first time you use your Elemental Dance feature, you do not have to spend a bardic inspiration. Every other time after the first until you finish a long rest, you spend the bardic inspiration as normal.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Conductor
entries: Also at 14th level, you’ve learned to pinpoint weakness in even the most resistant foes. When you deal damage to a creature with a resistance to acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder damage, you can choose to ignore their resistance until the end of the current turn.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Winter Domain
entries: Winter is a constant fear for many, as its cruelty and harsh conditions are often fatal. Worshipers of gods of the winter domain, such as Auril or Uller, offer prayers in exchange for mercy from the frigid winters. Clerics and priests of this domain often have the power to not only withstand these harsh environments but also offer guidance to those not as gifted through the harsh terrain.
*You can only choose the chill shield option when you cast this spell.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: {@i 1st-level Winter feature}
You gain proficiency in one of the following skills: athletics, intimidation, nature, or survival.

subclassFeature.name: Acolyte of Winter
entries: {@i 1st-level Winter feature}

You learn one cantrip of your choice of the following list: {@spell frostbite|XGE}, {@spell shape water|XGE}, or {@spell ray of frost}. The chosen cantrip counts as a cleric spell for you and does not count against your total number of cantrips known.

subclassFeature.name: Frost Forge
entries: {@i 1st-level Winter feature}

You can perform a 10-minute ritual to create a simple melee weapon that only you can use. You determine the physical appearance of the weapon and its shape, but not in a way that alters its statistics. You are proficient with the weapon and you add your spellcasting ability modifier to its attack and damage rolls instead of Strength or Dexterity. It has the light property and is considered magical for the purposes of overcoming non-magical resistances. On hit it deals 1d6 cold damage and reduces a creature’s speed by 10 feet until the start of your next turn, unless they have resistance or immunity to cold damage.

As a bonus action, you can summon your weapon to a free hand or dismiss the weapon causing it to disappear until you summon it again. Should your weapon be destroyed, you must perform another 10-minute ritual to create a new one. Your weapon is destroyed if you use your action to destroy it or if you die. The cold damage increases to 1d8 at 5th level and 1d10 at 16th level.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Winter’s Woe
entries: {@i 2nd-level Winter feature}

You summon a small portion of your diety's power to freeze creatures in their tracks. As an action, choose a point within 60 feet of you. Cold energy envelops the area in a 10-foot-radius of ice and snow. Each creature in the area makes a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes cold damage equal to 2d8 + your cleric level and their movement speed is reduced to 0 until the start of your next turn on a failed saving throw, and half as much damage and does not have their speed reduced on a successful one. A creature that has total cover from you is not affected. The area affected then becomes icy and is treated as difficult terrain for the next 10 minutes. Afterwhich, the ice and snow melts away.

subclassFeature.name: Winter’s Wayfinder
entries: {@i 6th-level Winter feature}

Your prayers to the gods of winter have been answered and you’ve been given a permanent blessing. You have resistance to cold damage and do not suffer the adverse effects of extreme cold. You ignore difficult terrain created by ice or snow and are not impeded by harsh environments in tundras or similar wastes.
In addition, you have advantage on Wisdom (Survival) and Intelligence (Nature) checks made related to tundras and similar cold environments.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: {@i 8th-level Winter feature}
You add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any cleric cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Arctic Aegis
entries: {@i 17th-level Winter feature}
You’ve become a sentinel of the cruel winter. You are immune to cold damage.
Friendly creatures within 10 feet of you have advantage on saving throws made against effects that deal cold damage, such as a dragon’s breath weapon or the cone of cold spell.

subclassFeature.name: Iceborn
entries: {@i 1st-level Iceborn feature}

Born from wastes made of ice and snow, your ancestors come from the faraway tundras. From the deep Abyss to the 5th layer of the Nine Hells, Stygia, your heritage can range from primordial beings of ice to even the most fiendish creatures. Your powers can also be gifts from these same otherworldly beings. Gods and Goddesses of Winter, such as Auril, are also prime candidates for the origin of these powers. Consult the Iceborn Origins table, or work with your DM on where your ice magic stems from.

entries.caption: Iceborn Origins
rows: You were born in a frozen wasteland, void of any other life except the ones who birthed you and other creatures that could withstand the frozen climate. Frost naturally builds up on your body even in extremely hot environments.

You were granted a boon of magic from the god/goddess of winter, giving you control over the very foundation of cryomancy. This boon grants you similar traits to that of an aasimar, including glowing eyes or even an icey halo.

One of or both of your parents were devils from the 5th level of hell, Stygia, giving you a natural connection to the magic found in the frigid climate, causing your skin to be naturally paler than what’s common from your race.

A White or Silver dragon is a long distant ancestor of yours, giving you various magical traits. Your teeth and fingernails are naturally sharper than what’s common for your race, but not enough to grant any physical improvement. You may even have lingering draconic scales.
An ice elemental gifted a relative of yours a magical boon. Snow slowly emits off your body and instantly melts when it hits the ground.
You were birthed or branded by a Demon from the Abyss. You have a magical brand on your body that is cold to the touch. Your skin surrounding the mark is frostbitten, but no pain can be felt from it.

subclassFeature.name: Cryomancy Magic
entries: Your magic comes from the frozen wastes, giving you the ability to always keep a cool head and give your enemies the cold shoulder. You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Cryomancy Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be a {@filter conjuration or transmutation spell from the sorcerer, warlock, or wizard spell list|spells|class=sorcerer;warlock;wizard|school=C,T|level=1;2;3;4;5} and if it deals damage, you must choose a spell that deals either cold, bludgeoning, piercing, slashing, or necrotic damage.

subclassFeature.name: Frozen Ancestry
entries: {@i 1st-level Iceborn feature}

Given your origins, you become accustomed to the creatures of your ancestry. Choose one of the following languages: Abyssal, Infernal, or Primordial. You learn to speak, read, and write the language you chose.

In addition, you have an innate ice magic that flows within you. You learn the {@spell Frostbite|XGE} cantrip and it does not count against your total number of known cantrips. If you already have this cantrip, choose one from: {@spell gust|XGE}, {@spell mending}, {@spell prestidigitation}, {@spell ray of frost}, or {@spell shape water|XGE}. You learn that cantrip instead.

subclassFeature.name: Iceborn Guide
entries: {@i 6th-level Iceborn feature}

Your heritage gives you an innate ability to push through the harsh environments of frozen wastes which allows you to make traversing these areas easier for you and your allies. You have resistance to cold damage and ignore the effects of extreme cold.

In addition, you ignore difficult terrain created by ice or snow and are not impeded by harsh environments in tundras or similar wastes. By spending 10 minutes you can magically provide this benefit to a number of allies of your choice equal to twice your proficiency bonus. This benefit lasts until the next time you finish a long rest. Creatures who gain this benefit do not gain your resistance to cold damage, but they do have advantage on saving throws made to resist the effects of extreme cold.

subclassFeature.name: Frigid Winds
entries: {@i 6th-level Iceborn feature}

Whenever you start casting a spell of 1st level or higher that deals cold damage, icy winds blow out from you. This icy wind causes creatures of your choice that you can see within 20 feet of you to take cold damage equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Frostbiting Mark
entries: {@i 14th-level Iceborn feature}

When a creature fails a saving throw against one of your 1st level or higher spells that deals cold damage, you can mark that creature with a chilling brand by spending 3 sorcery points. While marked with this brand, ice and frost slowly creeps into their body, granting them vulnerability to all damage until the end of your next turn. This renders any resistance or immunities they had useless until the effect fades. Once they next take damage after being marked, the frozen brand melts away, ending the effect. A creature is immune to the effects of this mark if they have resistance or immunity to cold damage.

You can only mark one creature at a time using this feature, and you can only mark creatures with this special brand a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all spent uses after a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Frozen Soul
entries: {@i 18th-level Iceborn feature}

Your mastery over cryomancy permanently changes your very being as you become one with your ancestry. You have immunity to cold damage and learn the {@spell Investiture of Ice|XGE} spell. If you already knew the {@spell Investiture of Ice|XGE} spell, you can choose another spell from the sorcerer spell list to learn instead. This spell does not count against your total number of sorcerer spells and you can cast it once at its lowest level without expending a spell slot.
Casting {@spell Investiture of Ice|XGE} in this way does not require concentration and lasts up to an hour rather than its normal duration of 10 minutes.

Whenever you cast {@spell Investiture of Ice|XGE} using a spell slot, its range becomes touch instead of self and you can target other creatures with the spell. Casting the spell at higher levels allows you to target one additional creature per spell slot level above 6th.

subclassFeature.name: Winter Walker
entries: You traverse primarily through colder environments. Tundras, certain layers of hell, perhaps even throughout the coldest parts of the feywild. Adapting to this specific environment, your magic also adapts to it, granting you certain cryomantic abilities.

subclassFeature.name: Freezing Strikes
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can augment your weapon strikes with body numbing magic, drawn from the frozen wastes of the tundras you traverse. When you hit a creature with a weapon, you can deal an extra 1d6 cold damage and their speed is reduced by 10 feet until the start of your next turn, you can only apply this extra damage and speed reduction once per turn.
The extra damage increases to 1d8 when you reach 11th level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Winter Walker Magic
entries: You learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Winter Walker Spells table. Each spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Frost Walker
entries: Also at 3rd level, you are adept at traversing through snowy environments and are an expert at guiding your allies through said environments. You have advantage on saving throws made to resist the effects of extreme cold and you do not suffer the effects of difficult terrain from ice and snow. By spending 10 minutes, you can magically bestow this benefit to any number of creatures within 30 feet of you up to your proficiency bonus plus your Wisdom modifier. This benefit lasts for 8 hours and once you grant it, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest.

If you chose the arctic terrain as your favored terrain from the Natural Explorer feature, you can grant this magical benefit as an action rather than spending 10 minutes and you can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest. When you use an action to grant these benefits, it instead only lasts for a minute.

subclassFeature.name: Warden of Winter
entries: At 7th level, you are aware of the dangers that lurk in the coldest of environments and your study over these creatures allows you to better prepare for them. You have resistance to cold damage and you have advantage on ability checks and saving throws made against effects that would reduce your movement in any way, including ways that would indirectly affect your speed such as being stunned or paralyzed which would take away your ability to move, even though it does not directly reduce your speed.
When you use your Frost Walker feature to grant other creatures the benefits of it, one of those creatures may also magically gain the benefits of this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Frozen Sentinel
entries: At 11th level, you can use your magic to ward yourself and your allies with a protective ice barrier. As a bonus action you can grant yourself and a number of allies within 30 feet of you up to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1) temporary hit points equal to your ranger level. While they have these temporary hit points, whenever a creature hits them with a melee attack from within 5 feet of them the attacker takes an amount of cold damage equal to your ranger level.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Preserving Ward
entries: At 15th level, you can use your magic to freeze over a dead creature, extending the duration needed to revive them with spells. You can cast gentle repose without expending a spell slot. You can do so a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

In addition, if you cast gentle repose on a creature whose been dead for no longer than a minute, some of your magic lingers within the corpse and tethers the soul to the creature before it can pass on into the afterlife. The cost for any material needed for a spell to bring the creature back to life, such as revivify, is halved until the spell ends.

subclassFeature.name: The Lore Hunter
entries: Some rangers specialize in the pursuit of knowledge, an archeologist traversing his way through an ancient tomb, hunting for strange and rare artifacts. Rangers of this conclave often dig up old relics of the past and try to decipher them to learn the secrets they hold.

subclassFeature.name: Lore Hunter Magic
entries: You learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Lore Hunter Spells table. Each spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Relic Knowledge
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you've been researching old, forgotten magic for years and have learned how to manifest it by tattooing runes onto your body. You gain proficiency in the History and Arcana skills. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of those proficiencies.
In addition, you have advantage on Intelligence (Investigation) and Wisdom (Perception) checks made to find or detect traps, or to see through illusions.

subclassFeature.name: Blast From the Past
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can empower your attacks with magic from the runes on your body. When you hit a creature with a weapon, you can deal an extra {@dice 1d6} force damage to the target, which can take this extra damage only once per turn.
The extra damage increases to 1d8 when you reach 11th level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Ritual Master
entries: Starting at 7th level, you can cast a ranger spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell prepared. In addition, when you ritual cast a spell, it takes you an extra 5 minutes instead of 10 to cast.

In addition, after you finish a long rest you can choose one of your prepared ranger spells, the chosen spell can be of a level no higher than half of your proficiency bonus (rounded down). The chosen spell is given the ritual tag until you next finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Detect Dungeon
entries: Also at 7th level, you can focus your mind to magically sense dungeons or ruins that contain valuable treasures, such as a dragon’s hoard or the temple of an ancient ruler. As an action, you detect the distance and direction to the closest dungeon or ruin within 10 miles of you. In order for a location to qualify for this feature, there must be enough treasure worth at least 1,000 gp or more.

Alternatively, you can name a creature or object associated and/or familiar with the dungeon or ruin and roll an Intelligence (Arcana) ability check. The DC equals the CR of the creature or 15 if it is an object. If the object is a magic item, the DC increases by 5 if it is a Rare or Very Rare item and by 10 if it is a Legendary item or an Artifact. If the target is protected by divination magic, you gain no information about it.
On a successful check, you learn the location of the target, as well as the distance and direction of it. You retain this knowledge for the next 24 hours, after which it is magically lost.
Once you’ve used this feature using either of the methods above, you cannot use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Ancient Wisdom
entries: Starting at 11th level, when you make an Intelligence ability check using a skill or tool, you can add your Wisdom modifier to the roll.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest. While you have no uses available, you can spend a spell slot of any level to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Relics of The Past
entries: Starting at 15th level, you're able to manifest a powerful item using old and forgotten magic. By performing a 1-hour ritual and expending a 3rd level or higher spell slot, you can manifest one of the following items, which lasts until you use this feature again or until you die:

items.name: Relic Talisman
entries: You create a magical talisman which wards the wearer with a protective aura. A creature wearing this talisman gains a +2 bonus to AC and saving throws.

items.name: Relic Armament
entries: You can create a non-magical martial or simple weapon, which becomes magical after it is created. The wielder has a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon and once per turn when they hit with it, it deals an additional 1d6 force damage.

items.name: Relic Ring
entries: You create a ring capable of storing magic within it. As an action, you can choose one of your prepared ranger spells and store it within the ring. The spell must be no higher than 3rd level. A creature can cast the spell from the ring once, without expending a spell slot or requiring material components. The spell uses your spell save DC and spell attack modifier. You can use an action to choose a different spell to store into the ring, taking out the previous one. Once a creature casts a spell from this ring, a creature cannot do so again until you finish a long rest.

items.name: Relic Aegis
entries: You create a set of light or medium non-magical armor, which becomes magical after it is created. The armor gives the wearer a +1 bonus to their AC and the wearer’s movement speed is increased by 10 feet.
Once you’ve manifested an item with this feature, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of The Frozen Wastes
entries: Druids of the Circle of The Frozen Wastes find safety in the cold. Few creatures can survive in the icy tundras and those that do often form pacts with these druidic tribes. Elementals, dragons, even the occasional wandering spirits often thrive in the cold.

Winter is an unavoidable part of nature, most flowers and crops perish during these times. However, there are other plants that flourish in the cold and the shade, perishing in the warmth and sunlight.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Your time surviving in the frozen wastes grants you access to certain spells. At 2nd level, you learn the ray of frost cantrip. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of Frozen Wastes Spells table.

Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

subclassFeature.name: Frigid Form
entries: At 2nd level, you gain the ability to channel your icy magic into a shiny elemental form. As a bonus action, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape feature to cover your body with freezing ice, rather than transforming into a beast form, and you gain 4 temporary hit points for each level you have in this class. While this feature is active, you gain the following benefits:

items: You add your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of +1) to the damage you deal with any druid cantrip or spell as additional cold damage.
Your melee weapon attacks deal an extra 1d6 cold damage to any target they hit.
You have resistance to cold damage.

entries: These benefits last for 10 minutes, until you lose all these temporary hit points, or until you use your Wild Shape again.

subclassFeature.name: Frozen Affinity
entries: Also at 2nd level, you are acclimated to cold temperatures and frozen terrain. You do not incur penalties from extreme cold. You also do not suffer from difficult terrain imposed by ice or snow.

subclassFeature.name: Frozen Fortification
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you transform your body temperature drops to freezing cold temperatures, making you more resilient against ailments. You gain the following benefits while your Frigid Form is active:

items: You have advantage on Constitution saving throws.
When you enter this form, you end any diseases you are afflicted with.

subclassFeature.name: Frozen Beast Form
entries: At 10th level, after you use your action to wild shape into a beast form, as part of that action you can immediately assume your Frigid Form simultaneously with your beast form. When you enter your Frigid Form in this way, you only gain 1 temporary hit point for each level you have in this class. At 16th level, the temporary hit points gained increases to 2 per level you have in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Archdruid of The Frozen Wastes
entries: At 14th level, you’ve obtained mastery over the elements of the frozen wastes. You have resistance to cold damage in your normal form and immunity to cold damage while in Frigid Form. Also, you add the wall of ice and otiluke's freezing sphere spells to your druid spell list and can prepare them as you would any other druid spell.

In addition, when you activate your Frigid Form, or as a bonus action on subsequent turns, you can unleash a powerful burst of icy wind. Each creature in a 20-foot cone originating from you makes a Constitution saving throw using your Spell Save DC or takes 3d8 cold damage and their movement speed is reduced by 10 feet on a failed save. On a success they take half as much damage and their speed is not reduced. The speed reduction lasts until the start of your next turn. You can use this blast a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, regaining all expended uses on a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of The Dragonkin
entries: Some druid circles follow and worship dragons as they can command the forces of nature themselves. Some druids among these circles are blessed by these dragons in exchange for their servitude.
Other druids are direct kin to these dragons, giving them the ability to take their shape for moments at a time, with the most powerful of these druids earning the title of "true dragons".

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Your direct link to the overwhelming magical power of dragons allows you to gain access to some of their own spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Circle of Dragons Spells table.

Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

subclassFeature.name: Dragonkin
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you learn to speak, read, and write Draconic or one other language of your choice. In addition, you’ve grown up around dragons, inheriting some of their magic. Choose chromatic, gem, or metallic. You can then choose one damage type that is associated with your chosen dragonkin. The damage type you choose is used by features you gain later.

entries.caption: Dragonkin Table
rows: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison

subclassFeature.name: Shape of the Dragonkin
entries: Also at 2nd level, you can assume the form of a minor dragon. As a bonus action, by expending a use of your wildshape you can assume this form instead of a beast shape. You gain 5 temporary hit points for each level you have in this class. When you assume this shape, You choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space, merges into your new form, or is worn by it. Equipment that merges with the form has no effect until you leave the form. While this feature is active, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Natural Weapons
entries: You have a natural weapon in the form of a bite, claw, or tail (you choose when you make the attack). It counts as a simple melee weapon for you, and you add your Strength or Dexterity for the bonus to attack and damage rolls made with these natural weapons, as normal. On hit, these natural weapons deal {@dice 1d8} bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage (you choose when you make the attacks).

items.name: Natural Defense
entries: You have a thick scaley hide that protects you from harm. Your AC equals 13 + Wisdom modifier. In addition, you have resistance to the damage type associated with your Dragonkin feature.

items.name: Dragon Form
entries: Your shape changes to resemble that of a dragon. You determine the specifics of your appearance, so long as it fits within the parameters of a typical medium sized dragon or dragon-like beast. Your creature type becomes dragon and if you are smaller than medium, you become medium.

You follow the same restrictions as you do for your wild shape for the purposes of spellcasting, however you can still speak while in this form. These benefits last for 10 minutes, until you lose all these temporary hit points, or until you use your Wild Shape again.

subclassFeature.name: Breath of the Dragonkin
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can channel the draconic energies within and exhale it into a powerful magical burst.

While your shape of the dragonkin is active, by expending a spell slot of any level you can use an action to make an exhalation of draconic energy in either a 20-foot cone or a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide (your choice). Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC. They take {@dice 2d8} damage of the type associated with your dragonkin per level of the expended spell slot on a failed save, or half as much on a success.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. While you have no uses available, you can expend a use of your wild shape to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Young Dragonkin
entries: Also at 6th level, your connection to draconic magic grows more powerful, granting you new abilities. While your shape of the dragonkin is active, you gain the following benefits:

items: If you are smaller than large, you become large. If you lack the room to become Large, your size doesn't change.

Your natural weapons count as magical for the purposes of overcoming non-magical resistances. In addition, you can attack twice with your natural weapons when you take the attack action instead of once.
Your walking speed increases by 10 feet and you gain either a swim speed or a climb speed equal to your walking speed (you choose when you assume this form).

subclassFeature.name: Adult Dragonkin
entries: Starting at 10th level, your growth as a dragonkin advances to a more adulterated state, granting you even greater power. While your shape of the dragonkin is active, you gain the following benefits:

items: If you are smaller than huge, you become huge. If you lack the room to become Huge, your size changes to large, unless you lack the room to become large, then your size doesn’t change.
When you deal damage with your natural weapons, you add an additional 1d8 damage of the type associated with your dragonkin.
You gain a magical flying speed equal to twice your walking speed. You can choose whether or not you grow wings when you assume this form.

subclassFeature.name: Ancient Dragonkin
entries: At 14th level, you’ve advanced to the highest stage you can inherit from your dragonkin. While your shape of the dragonkin is active, you gain the following benefits:

items: You add your Wisdom modifier to the damage rolls of your natural weapons and your breath of the dragonkin.
The bonus damage you add from your adult dragonkin feature increases to 2d8.

As a bonus action, you can spend a number of hit dice up to your proficiency bonus. Roll the spent hit dice and add your Constitution modifier, you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to the result. These temporary hit points replace any you gained from your shape of the dragonkin feature, but count towards maintaining it.
You have immunity to the damage type associated with your dragonkin.

entries: In addition, you can now maintain your shape of the dragonkin feature for up to a number of hours equal to the amount you can for your wild shape feature. You still lose the form if you lose all of the temporary hit points gained from that feature or this one.
